comment.author: 41909278@N08
comment._content:
This design started out life as a BT-9B. NAA took one of the 'B's off the line and fitted it with a Harvard canopy, wing and tail feathers. Only one of these interim aircraft was constructed but the design evolved, with the addition of a slightly different wing and a metal clad fuselage in place of the original fabric covered tubing, into the BT-14. The Wright Whirlwind engine was replaced with a more powerful P&W R-985 Wasp Junior. Like its predecessor, the BT-9, this aircraft was never known as the Yale.

Doug MacPhail
